data.text:
TOBY LAING

Weâre lucky enough to have Peter here. Heâs touring different parts of the world at the moment, DJing. Heâs just been over in New Zealand and Brazil and Uruguay. Heâs here in Melbourne as well for our show too. Of course, he needs not really much of an introduction. He and his equally famous colleagues are phenomena of global music coming out of Manchester in the mid-â70s. Joy Division trends morphing into New Order somewhere along the line and involved in many other projects as well as producer and musician. The bass stylist, all of those things. Itâs really good to have you here, Peter. Thanks for comingâ¦

PETER HOOK

Thank you.

TOBY LAING

Being in a position like this, addressing a group of people about your music. Itâs probably not the kind of thing that you were imagining all those years ago when you were just getting into music.

PETER HOOK

It all began in 1977. If youâd have gone along to somebody and said you wanted to learn music, then they would have thought you were an idiot. I think itâs quite interesting these days, and Iâm not too sure as a self-taught musician whether I could say it was good or bad. I donât think Iâm expert enough to say that because I came up the other way. I came the back stairs route of learning to play music and being in a group. So, it seems quite odd to me that people teach people how to be in groups. Itâs quite strange so maybe some of you could enlighten me to whether it works or not.

TOBY LAING

It seems like you just picked up an instrument at a certain point and you were inspired by a certain performance or by what came to be known later as punk.

PETER HOOK

Yeah, Iâd never been interested in music apart from listening to records and stuff like that. Iâd never played a musical instrument apart from the recorder at school. I went to see the Sex Pistols at the Lesser Free Trade Hall in Manchester in June of 1976. I went out and bought a bass guitar the next day. Donât ask me why I did that because I donât know. because Iâd never even considered.

I think the thing was that when I saw the Sex Pistols, which was sort of at the end of my teenage years, obviously 20, I didnât have a clue what the fuck I was going to do for the rest of my life. It was like, I saw the answer. I just saw the Sex Pistols spit at people on stage, and I thought âI want to do that. I want to be able to spit at people onstage.â As long as they donât spit at me. You have got to get it right, you can spit them but they canât spit at you.

I thought, âRight, to be in a group, you obviously need an instrument.â So, I went out and paid Â£35 for a bass guitar because my mate, Bernard [Sumner], had a guitar. Youâre not allowed to have two guitars in a punk group. Or you werenât then. That was it. We were a group. Then, we thought, âShit, weâve got no music.â [laughs] Sort of one little oversight. So, we started writing music and that was it. Iâve been doing that for 30 years.

TOBY LAING

So, you picked up a bass. You werenât necessarily drawn to it. Within that punk idea. thereâs a lot of freedom, but there are a couple of rules about a certain approach to musicâ¦

PETER HOOK

Yeah. We sort of broke that quite soon, really, because the first music we wrote was obviously punky as in the fact that you couldnât play. I think that it was quite soon that your tastes are refined. My musical taste, as in the people I was listening to, I suppose youâd have to say was quite refined. I liked The Doors, Led Zeppelin, Deep Purple, all your heavy metal stuff that was big. I suppose youâre listening to a lot of different slow and fast music, whereas in punk it was all one pace [growls a punk singer]. Like that, you see.

We soon got bored with that. That didnât get us. I know that bands still play like that today, but it didnât get us, so we sort of moved off musically quite quickly. The rules of punk, which I still sort of hold dear, is that you donât necessarily do what people say. The great thing about forming a group, Iâve found, was that you could tell everyone to fuck off because you were in a group, and somehow you got away with it because you were in a group. You went to television studios, you were drunk, you were obnoxious, you just did what you wanted, you fell over, you spewed up, and that was in a group. It was great.

Itâs quite interesting now when you see things like Pop Idol and all this sort of reality thing because groups have to be completely different. They have to be nice to people. Well, the way that I was brought up was independently. We had an independent record label, which means we didnât have really have anybody telling us what to do. The only drawback from that was that no one would lend you any money. As we all know in this world money is very important in learning, I suppose. The thing that we were always self-financed as a group on every concert we did, every tour we did, and every record we did which hasnât changed. Nobody funded us. Nobody owned or told Joy Division or New Order what to do, which was very, very lucky position to be in, and I suppose thatâs what made me whatever it is I am now.

TOBY LAING

I think thatâs what I was getting at. Itâs like taking that idea of being able to do what you want with your music, not being limited to a certain kind of instrumentation, you started to, early on, to utilize a whole bunch of thingsâ¦ electronic instruments.

PETER HOOK

Yeah, but I think the thing that youâd have to admit is that obviously, you had a talent. Iâve met a lot of people that, even though theyâve been great people, have not really had a talent, and talent comes from no one knows where, does it? Talent comes from God if you like.

TOBY LAING

It seems like, at one point, talent was coming from Manchester.

PETER HOOK

Yeah, again, Iâve been very lucky in that I live in Manchester. I donât know why so many great groups come out of Manchester, I wish I did. I mean, when I think that my friends, The Stone Roses, The Happy Mondays, The Charlatans, Buzzcocks â Christ, even down to that ginger-haired twat Mick Hucknall [laughter]. Thereâs still a lot of people that have done something in music. Inspiral Carpets, the list is endless of people that came from Manchester.

TOBY LAING

You donât have a theory about the culture of Manchester? What might lead to this?

PETER HOOK

Bernard, his thing was that it was so fucking awful that everybody would always want to get out of it. So, you form a group to get out of it which, I suppose is just as good a reason as any. I still live in Manchester. Itâs still very important to me. Ironically, itâs still is important musically. The Smiths, donât forget the Smiths. Now, Badly Drawn Boy, I Am Kloot, Elbow, Doves. Still, a lot of groups come from Manchester â¦ I mean, we kick Liverpoolâs ass, manâ¦ itâs fucking great.

TOBY LAING

The early days, the independent label â¦ Kind of the freedom it offered, but also, obviously, the restriction of not having any funding or having to be self-funded â¦ How did that loose business structure deal with the popularity of â¦

PETER HOOK

Well, I mean, business-wise, obviously, now that Iâm knocking 51, Iâm quite good at business, but I did learn the hard way and we got ripped off loads and loads of times. It was quite interesting signing Red Bullâs contract because it had a clause at the end that said I agreed that it was a reasonable and fair contract. I crossed it off because I didnât think it was a reasonable and fair contract, but I still signed it. You spend your life going through things like that. I was very lucky in that I got to the ripe, old age of 40 before I signed a contract. The only contract we had was when we signed to London Records in 1996 or something. Before that, Iâd never had to sign a contract. because we were punks and we didnât sign contracts. It was quite interesting. So, business-wise, you do get taken advantage of, but the thing is, as my mother used to say âYouâll see the back of them all, Peterâ and very luckily, I have.

The thing about doing it independently and being free is that things could happen very quickly. I remember writing âLove Will Tear Us Apartâ in an afternoon with Ian, and he went away and did the lyrics, and then we came back, and we didnât even have the tape machine in those days, so for the record companies to hear it, they had to come hear us perform it, which was quite interesting because itâs quite interesting when you think that an LP like Unknown Pleasures, because we were poor, it only existed in our heads.

It didnât exist anywhere on tape because we were too poor to record it. We didnât have anything to record it on, so the only time it existed was when we played it together, which was quite a startling concept when you think how much you take for granted being able to listen to music these days and that the way that you write music in layers across a computer. You have an ultimate variety of doing whatever you want to it. It sometimes amazes me that, I think, that Unknown Pleasures only existed in our heads, and the only time we could play was when the four of us played it together.

Again, the thing was that, yeah, we played our manager âLove Will Tell Us Apart.â âThatâs good, lads. I think that might do all right that. Iâll get Tony Wilson down,â and he got Tony Wilson down, and Tony Wilson heard it and went, âYeah, thatâs good. That could be good. Yeah, yeah, yeah. Weâll go and record that.â Phone Martin Hannett and we phoned Martin Hannett, and we went and recorded it, and that was âLove Will Tear Us Apartâ done like in a week and out. Unfortunately, it coincided with Ian [Curtis]âs death. God rest his soul, but the point was that you could do things quickly in those days. Everything didnât have to be planned like a military campaign. You canât release a single until you finish your album, till youâve got your video done, till this and that. All that bollocks.

TOBY LAING

You just mentioned Martin Hannett and describing yourself as a self-taught musician. You picked up a base and just started playing it, almost luck of the draw.

PETER HOOK

Luck of the draw [laughs].

TOBY LAING

Did youâ¦ Youâve since worked a lot in the studio as a producer, self-produced albums and also your own projects. Youâve produced The Stone Roses.

PETER HOOK

Itâs what I hated about producers, and what I hated about Martin Hannett, in particular, was that he didnât do what the group wanted because I think that producers, while they may be right or they might be right â âMaybe the chorus is too long, or your vocal is slightly out of tune. That drum loopâs too busy, or da de da de da daâ â the thing is that they finish the work, they get paid, and theyâd go, and youâd have to live with it and talk about it ad infinitum. The thing isâ¦ is that my view of producing, which is probably why I never get asked to produce anybody any more is that the bands should always be the one thatâs happy, not the producer, not the record company because the band have to live with it. Whenever I have producedâ¦ I produced The Stone Roses and people like that. Iâve always, if I did something the band didnât like, we had to change it because I always felt, as a musician, that they have to live with it and not me. Thatâs my production ethic.

TOBY LAING

Are you going back into the studio to produce anything in the near [future]?

PETER HOOK

To be honest with you, production is one of the most difficult and time-consuming jobs, and even though you get paid for it, if you have a hit album then you can make a fortune. I find it so consuming and such hard work that I prefer playing in the group, really. My greatest love is playing in the group. I do DJing because the other members of the group donât want to play, so I needed something to fill me time, so when Mani asked me to DJ on Primal Scream, I said yes.

TOBY LAING

That initial phase when you had developed this popularity in Manchester and outside of Manchester and around the UK. Taking that music then to other places, what was theâ¦

PETER HOOK

You see, that sounds easy. It wasnât that easy because we used to play to nobody as Joy Division. We played a gig in Oldham, which is near Manchester, and there was nobody there. No one.

I remember, two girls came in after about 20 minutes. They walked up to the front of the stage because there was nobody in there, we were playing, and we stopped. The girl went âHey, are The Frantic Elevatorsâ

We went âNo, no. Weâre Joy Division.â

They went âFuck, weâre in the wrong place,â and they went.

When you play to no people, it doesnât matter, does it. We were playing the same set, the Unknown Pleasures set that six months later, or a year later youâd be playing to thousands of people. Thereâs no rhyme or reason to it, at all. The thing is, I suppose as a performer and as a musician, every single time you play, youâre tested.

I was saying before, that when I DJed at Parklife [the Australian music festival] on Saturday, which was quite ironic, because when I walked home because I started off with a slow tune and everybody had been playing fast stuff, someone threw something at me, which was a crushed up Red Bull canâ¦ I took the money with relish today for that. It happens all the time. Sometimes you go down well, sometimes you go down crap. You donât take your success anywhere with you. Everywhere you go can be really, really difficult because it attacks your heart and your soul if youâre up there playing and someone spits at you or throws something at you or shouts, âGet off, youâre shit,â or whatever. âYou cheeky bastard,â you know, it gets you right âin there.â The good thing about being in a group is at least youâve got your mates to [grumbles]. When youâre DJing, you havenât got shit. [Pretends to be scared] âWhereâs that big guy gotâ¦ the one that was on the end,â you know?

I mean, performing attacks you every time. Itâs very easy to lose your battle. Or to lose everything, just by one guy going [makes offensive hand gesture]. I actually find it worse now because Iâm sober. âMy nameâs Peter, and Iâm an alcoholic â¦â Now that Iâm sober, I see everything. Whereas before, when I was drinking I didnât see anything, I was just [growls]â¦ Itâs funny, itâs made it actually harder. The thing that puzzles me is, I started off sober, so I donât know why that changed. Been sober for years, playing. Now it bugs the shit out me, when people are pissed.

TOBY LAING

Thereâs some unpleasant experiences. As a performer, something has been compelling you to continue writing songs with this group of people when, at times, it seems like itâs been a difficult relationship with your other colleagues in the bands.

PETER HOOK

The difficult thing for me is that it is the only thing I know is writing songs and playing them. Itâs very difficult for me to sit there and say to my children, âOh, you should do your exams because itâs very important.â He goes to me, âWell youâve never got any exams, and look at you! Youâre alright.â Iâm like, âThatâs not the point!â Sound like me dad.

Itâs the only thing Iâve known is writing and performing music, and sometimes when Iâm really, really pissed off with them all, and I think, âShit, thatâs it. Iâve had enough of that knobhead, heâs driving me mad. Iâm going, Iâve had enough â¦â

Then I think, âWell, what you going to do?â

âOh, OK, Iâll play â¦â Itâs a strange world, isnât it?

TOBY LAING

Obviously, you do get some form ofâ¦ the expression of it obviously is something thatâ¦

PETER HOOK

The expression isâ¦ I couldnât even explain. Somebody, when I playedâ¦ this is name-dropping. Sorry. When we did Glastonbury last year, there was 120,000 people there, and they all sat there staring at you. It was an absolute bizarre situation to be in. People all caked in mud, off their tits on psychedelic mushrooms, chanting along to âLove Will Tear Us Apart,â how could you explain something like that? Itâs pretty good. Itâs great. Itâs nice to be appreciated. Itâs nice to have your ego massaged in one way or another. The thing is, is that when you sat somewhere in the four oâclock in the morning, trying to think of a word that rhymes with witchâ¦ We always used to call them âfive oâclock in the morningâ lyrics.

âOh, fuck. Can you just put that in, and fucking letâs get out of here.â Then, you have that side of it, the really difficult side, the writing side and also dealing with the business side. Then the great bit is to walk out on stage and have them all scream at you, I suppose, and enjoy what you do. The satisfaction is amazing. Itâs not real, though, you know. As you finish, you still have to clean up dog shit and all that.

TOBY LAING

Iâm not sure if youâre sick of talking about the whole situation where you found yourself not only in a band that was pretty busy but also, in a band that was involved in various business enterprises such as, a certain place of entertainment called the HaÃ§ienda.

PETER HOOK

Our record company and our manager decided that because we had nowhere to go in Manchester, we should open our own club. So we did, and in all fairness, the club did change. If any of you went clubbing. Heâs yawning, he must have been out there last night. It changed the face of clubbing and with acid house music. Sort of created dance in England and Europe. The whole ecstasy thing just went completely through the roof.

The club was â¦ It was a very difficult thing because when you worked out how many people had been in the HaÃ§ienda in the fifteen years it was open, you reckon that each of them had probably cost New Order and Joy Division about ten quid each. So weâd lost that much money on the club. Even though your accountant kept saying to you it was great promotion andâ¦ When things are going bad and you sat there a bit skint thinking, âHmm, I could have done without that promotion, really.â Would rather have had the money, you know. But weâre artists, arenât we?

TOBY LAING

Yeah, the promotional value â¦ obviously, you had to the brunt of it, but itâs a very famous place and the whole scene with Factory Records and the HaÃ§ienda and New Order.

PETER HOOK

Yeah, I mean thanks to 24 Hour Party People, the film, it sort of resurrected it around the world and made itâ¦ it was a very special place. The thing is, our manager did say to us, âI think weâve done well out of Manchester, weâve done well out of music, we should give something back.â We didnât realize that he meant everything [laughs]. We thought he just meant a little bit of it. A tenner, maybe. Not everything.

So, but, yeah, mistakes you make. You sign a little bit of paper when youâre hungover, and then the next thing you know, itâs kicking you up the ass for 20 years, isnât it? We have to say weâre still here and we havenât done badly out of it. Weâre stillâ¦ Iâm a very successful musician, and Iâve done well. Itâs been hard work. I mean, I still have to work now. I work for a living. I work because I love it. Thatâs what my wife always says, âYou fucking love it. Shut up moaning.â But I do love it, but I do still have to work for a living.

TOBY LAING

When I just think of theâ¦ when I think of your musical output and the various styles that itâsâ¦ You may not be conscious of it, being in the middle of it all, but you seem to be drawing from a lot of different places throughout the years. You obviously-

PETER HOOK

Yeah, weâve been really lucky for being in the right place at the right time. Youâd have to say that Joy Division, Factory, New Order, HaÃ§ienda had it. They were definitely in the right place at the right time. I think we write great music, which I think is theâ¦ you have to believe in yourself at some point. You have to be able to stand up and say, âThis is great, fuck the lot of you.â Even when it bombs on its ass, you have to say, âWell I still think it was great.â I write music for myself. I donât write it for, as much as I hate to say it, for you lot or anybody. I write it because I love it and because when I finish it, I think itâs fantastic. I donât tailor-make my music for audiences.

I think that even as a DJ, thereâs an aspect of tailoring your music. Like when I played in Wellington the other night, I was saying to you [points to interviewer], it was an indie crowd, and they were all moaning because I was playing dance music. The devil in me thinks, âWell fuck you then. Tough shit. Shouldnât have come, should you?â [laughs] You know, itâs like that. Then the other side of me thinks, âAm I going to get beaten up? Well, maybe I should put some on.â

TOBY LAING

When you DJ, itâs all kinds of stuff that youâre playing?

PETER HOOK

Yeah. I always found DJing absolutely ridiculous. I thought they were a bunch of egotistical pricks. I was right. Now Iâm an egotistical prick as well, itâs fucking great, isnât it? I guess someone said I was being an egotistical prick. No, I didnât understand it, to be honest. The only reason I began DJing was because Mani, the bass player of Primal Scream who was my friend, he said to me âItâs a great way of getting pissed for nothing.â

I thought âWell, that sounds interesting,â so I went to see him. We did a gig in Barcelona, which was absolutely hilarious because he was twatted and I didnât do anything. I just stood there answering questions about why New Order donât gig.

[Spanish accent] âWhy you never play in Spain? Why you never come here?â

He was throwing the records at people when they were annoying him. He was spinning, he was scratching at one point. Really into it and I went over and said, âMani, thatâs not on, that.â [laughter] âOh fucking alright, OK then.â I thought, âThis seems like a proper good laugh, this DJing.â That was the reason why I started DJing and I went through the drinking part of it. Getting completely pissed and chasing girls around stuff like that. Which Iâm not proud of.

Then I got into the musical side of it. Started putting music together that I thought would be good. To be honest, after being in the studio with New Order for three yearsâ¦ the thing that pissed me off most was that we hadnât been playing. We had been in the studio for three years, we had done a record, but we werenât doing any gigs, which I found very irksome. I started DJing and then started thinking about music to play to people and obviously got into the whole reason of why DJs DJ, because they put music together in a way that makes it entertaining, makes it have an impact and people take it for granted. I mean I can count onâ¦ I can count on everybodyâs hands here [gestures to audience] however many times I have been into a club and never noticed the DJ. But if he wasnât there, weâd all be a bit bored, wouldnât we? Itâs one of those funny things. I was very scathing when I began it, and now I think theyâre great.

TOBY LAING

I mean, regardless of how incredibly out of it a lot of people must have been at the time, the club we were talking about before seems to be a bit of a landmark for DJs exposing crowds to music, which they may not otherwise have heard, putting it together in a way that they may not have experienced before, and itâs led to various different subcultures around the world.

PETER HOOK

We had the record in the HaÃ§ienda of paying a DJ the most that a DJ had ever been paid, which was Sasha for his first sold-out night in the HaÃ§ienda. He got paid Â£2,000 in 1988 or â89, which was quite a lot of money then. So, I suppose in a way, that whole DJ-as-superstar culture came from acid house andâ¦ itâs funny as a musician when youâre not a DJ, you just think, âWell, all they do is play records. Theyâre playing our records. Thatâs all theyâre doing.â I mean, obviously, thereâs more to it than that, but to my mind, I still think the musician, I should have to say, is the most important person, because they wouldnât have anything to play, would they? The reason most DJs get into writing their own stuff is because they get paid more for playing their own stuff than they get paid for playing your stuff or my stuff. Thatâs how they make money on publishing. Thatâs a step. Itâs a career step, I suppose. Hope I havenât disillusioned anybody there.

TOBY LAING

So, you came out of the studio last year after three years, did you say?

PETER HOOK

Well, yeah, I mean, off and on. When you get to our age, as daft as it sounds, you donât do it the way that you did. I used to go in the studio and Iâd do 18 hours. Iâd just go back, sleep, go back to the studio. I did that for 20-odd years, you know. Youâd lose a few girlfriends, wives. You miss a few children growing up, and then you think, âWhat the fuck am I doing?â So you do it in a different way now. I do it as a 10-to-6, as a job. I think itâs that interesting thing that when you start, you live for the group. As you get on through it, you do the group to live. Itâs justâ¦ Iâve done the intensity, and Iâve done all that lot. Iâm very lucky in that I have a bedrock that enables me to come on a jolly to Australia and play in front of a few people in a park in Melbourne or whatever. Iâm sort of very lucky. I get paid for doing it. Itâs great. But without the bedrock of the work that I put in, the intensity of that, that takes you to the edge in many ways, then you wouldnât have that freedom to do it. I think Iâve paid my dues.

TOBY LAING

You just mentioned before writing, âLove Will Tear Us Apartâ in an afternoon or an evening. That actual songwriting process, how is itâ¦ How many different forms does that take?

PETER HOOK

To me, it only takes two forms. Either it comes really quickly or it takes forever. If you look at a song like âBlue Mondayâ that took a hell of a long time to write. because of the technology we were using, the way that Bernard and Stephen [Morris] approach the technology was fantastic because I often found it boring as shit, and I would have been happy just to play on the guitars, and not be music at all. I found it really dull and tiresome, but they persevered and went through all the controlled voltage and building their own drum machines and working your way through of joining synths together to do pulses, to split off.

We had a guy who builtâ¦ We used a drum machine that came from an organ, like your granny has, playing bossa nova, waltz and all that. We took it out and got this guy to rebuild it and make it so you have separate outputs for each instrument. We did that in 1980. We used that on stage, which was actually a bizarre thing to use on stage from your grannyâs room. To fire the drum machine, a guy converted it from controlled voltage so that you can pulse a synth that Bernard built from a kit in England called the Transcendent 2000 â which never fucking worked.

We went through all that, and basically, it consumed you, unbelievably, the amount of work you had to put in. Very lucky these days, you can just buy it and turn it on. Youâve got a complete home studio within about half an hour with as many sounds as you want. Itâs incredible. Thatâs why it was really nice when I was watching the girl downstairs playing the squeeze box. It was absolutely wonderful to hear an instrument. Itâs really nice. Normally whenever I hear an instrument, I press a button and an instrument comes. Itâs really nice [that] some people actually play still. Itâs fantastic.

But the technology to do âBlue Mondayâ was unbelievable. When we think that weâve Prophet Five in 1980, we paid Â£2,000 for a Prophet Five. God knows how much that is today. Probably 25, 30 grand or something like thatâ¦

TOBY LAING

Yeahâ¦

PETER HOOK

Believable. We had five of them because they were so unreliable that you couldnât rely on one to play. You had to have three set up, ready to switch them over if they went down on stage, and two in the back for when the other three went. Literally like roulette.
